used: 1993 – The independent Slovak Republic and Czech Republic are established after the dissolution of Czechoslovakia.
1959 – The Soviet probe Luna 1 becomes the first artificial object to overcome Earth's gravitational pull.
1977 – Apple Computer Inc. is founded.
2004 – NASA's Spirit rover successfully lands on Mars.
1933 – Construction begins on one of the world's most famous bridges, the Golden Gate Bridge, in San Francisco.
1912 – New Mexico becomes the 47th U.S. state.
1610 – Galileo Galilei observes the four largest moons of Jupiter for the first time.
1958 – At the age of 14, Bobby Fischer becomes the youngest U.S. Chess Champion.
2007 – Steve Jobs introduces the first iPhone from Apple.
1920 – The League of Nations, the predecessor to the UN, is established.
1922 – Insulin is successfully used for the first time in Toronto to treat diabetes in a human.
1966 – The television series Batman, starring Adam West, premieres in the USA.
1898 – French writer Émile Zola publishes his famous open letter 'J'accuse...!' in connection with the Dreyfus affair.
1954 – Marilyn Monroe marries baseball legend Joe DiMaggio.
2001 – Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia, is launched.
1920 – Prohibition, banning the production and sale of alcohol, goes into effect in the USA.
1706 – Benjamin Franklin, American inventor, diplomat, and one of the Founding Fathers, is born.
1778 – English captain James Cook discovers the Hawaiian Islands.
1853 – Giuseppe Verdi's opera 'Il trovatore' premieres in Rome.
1961 – John F. Kennedy is inaugurated as the 35th President of the USA.
1976 – The supersonic transport aircraft Concorde takes off on its first commercial flight.
1984 – Apple airs its famous '1984' commercial during the Super Bowl, introducing the Macintosh computer.
1960 – Jacques Piccard and Don Walsh descend to the bottom of the Mariana Trench in the bathyscaphe Trieste.
1848 – Gold is discovered in California, sparking the Gold Rush.
1924 – The first Winter Olympic Games begin in Chamonix, France.
1905 – The Cullinan, the largest diamond in history, is found in South Africa.
1880 – Thomas Edison patents the electric light bulb.
1986 – The Space Shuttle Challenger explodes shortly after liftoff, killing all 7 crew members.
1886 – Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-powered automobile.
1969 – The Beatles perform their last public concert on the roof of the Apple Corps building in London.
1958 – The USA launches its first successful satellite, Explorer 1.
1884 – The first volume of the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
1943 – The Battle of Stalingrad, a key turning point in World War II, ends.
1959 – The Day the Music Died: Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and The Big Bopper die in a plane crash.
2004 – Mark Zuckerberg launches the social network 'Thefacebook', later known as Facebook.
1953 – Walt Disney's animated film 'Peter Pan' premieres in the USA.
1952 – Elizabeth II becomes Queen of the United Kingdom after the death of her father, George VI.
1964 – The Beatles arrive in the USA for the first time, beginning the 'British Invasion'.
1828 – Jules Verne, French science fiction writer, is born.
1969 – The Boeing 747 'Jumbo Jet' takes off for the first time.
1996 – IBM's supercomputer Deep Blue defeats reigning world chess champion Garry Kasparov for the first time.
1990 – Nelson Mandela is released from prison after 27 years.
1809 – Charles Darwin, British naturalist and author of the theory of evolution, is born.
1633 – Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome to face the Inquisition for his heliocentric views.
2005 – The video-sharing website YouTube is founded.
1564 – Galileo Galilei, Italian astronomer, physicist, and philosopher, is born.
1923 – Howard Carter opens the burial chamber of Pharaoh Tutankhamun.
1904 – Giacomo Puccini's opera 'Madama Butterfly' premieres in Milan.
1930 – American astronomer Clyde Tombaugh discovers the planet Pluto.
1473 – Nicolaus Copernicus, the astronomer who formulated the heliocentric model of the universe, is born.
1962 – John Glenn becomes the first American to orbit the Earth.
1953 – Francis Crick and James Watson discover the structure of the DNA molecule.
1997 – Scientists in Scotland announce they have successfully cloned a sheep, Dolly.
1455 – Johannes Gutenberg prints the first book using movable type, the Gutenberg Bible.
1981 – Buckingham Palace announces the engagement of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.
1964 – Muhammad Ali (then Cassius Clay) becomes the heavyweight champion of the world after defeating Sonny Liston.
1935 – Robert Watson-Watt demonstrates the functioning of radar for the first time.
1879 – Saccharin, the first artificial sweetener, is discovered.
1953 – James Watson and Francis Crick announce to their colleagues that they have discovered the 'secret of life'—the structure of DNA.
1504 – Christopher Columbus uses his knowledge of a lunar eclipse to persuade Jamaican natives to provide him with supplies.
1936 – The construction of the Hoover Dam in the USA is completed.
1965 – The film 'The Sound of Music' premieres in the USA.
1931 – 'The Star-Spangled Banner' is officially adopted as the national anthem of the USA.
1789 – The United States Congress meets for the first time in New York City.
1970 – The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons comes into force.
1899 – The Bayer company registers Aspirin as a trademark.
1876 – Alexander Graham Bell is granted a patent for the invention of the telephone.
1910 – International Women's Day is established at the International Socialist Women's Conference in Copenhagen.
1959 – The first Barbie doll is introduced to the market.
1876 – The first successful telephone call is made between Alexander Graham Bell and his assistant.
2011 – An earthquake and subsequent tsunami in Japan cause a disaster at the Fukushima nuclear power plant.
1989 – Tim Berners-Lee submits a proposal for a system that would later become the World Wide Web.
1781 – William Herschel discovers the planet Uranus.
1879 – Albert Einstein, one of the most important physicists of all time, is born.
44 BC – Julius Caesar is assassinated in Rome.
1926 – Robert Goddard launches the first liquid-fueled rocket.
461 – Saint Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland, dies.
1965 – Cosmonaut Alexei Leonov performs the first human spacewalk.
1931 – Gambling is legalized in Nevada.
1852 – Harriet Beecher Stowe's novel 'Uncle Tom's Cabin', which strongly influenced the fight against slavery, is published.
1963 – The federal prison on Alcatraz Island in San Francisco is closed.
1997 – Comet Hale-Bopp makes its closest approach to Earth.
1919 – Benito Mussolini founds his fascist movement in Milan.
1882 – German physician Robert Koch announces the discovery of the bacterium that causes tuberculosis.
1655 – Dutch astronomer Christiaan Huygens discovers Titan, Saturn's largest moon.
1827 – German composer Ludwig van Beethoven dies.
1977 – The deadliest aviation accident in history occurs at the airport on the island of Tenerife.
1930 – The Turkish cities of Constantinople and Angora are renamed Istanbul and Ankara.
1886 – John Pemberton brews the first batch of Coca-Cola in Atlanta.
1858 – Hyman Lipman patents the pencil with an attached eraser.
1889 – The Eiffel Tower is officially opened in Paris.
1976 – Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne found Apple.
1513 – Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de León lands in Florida.
1973 – Martin Cooper makes the first mobile phone call.
1968 – Martin Luther King Jr. is assassinated in Memphis.
1998 – The Akashi Kaikyō Bridge in Japan, the world's longest suspension bridge, is opened.
1896 – The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1948 – The World Health Organization (WHO) is established.
1974 – Hank Aaron breaks Babe Ruth's record for the most home runs in Major League Baseball.
1865 – The American Civil War ends with General Lee's surrender.
1912 – The luxury liner Titanic sets sail on its first and only voyage.
1970 – The Apollo 13 mission launches from Kennedy Space Center.
1961 – Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human in space.
1970 – The Apollo 13 crew reports 'Houston, we've had a problem' after an oxygen tank explosion.
1865 – U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is assassinated.
1912 – The Titanic sinks in the North Atlantic after colliding with an iceberg.
1943 – Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann accidentally discovers the psychedelic effects of LSD.
1964 – Ford introduces the Mustang at the New York World's Fair.
1955 – Albert Einstein dies.
1775 – The American Revolutionary War begins with the battles of Lexington and Concord.
1902 – Marie and Pierre Curie isolate the radioactive element radium.
753 BC – According to tradition, Rome is founded.
1970 – Earth Day is celebrated for the first time.
1616 – English playwright William Shakespeare dies.
1990 – The Hubble Space Telescope is launched into orbit by the Space Shuttle Discovery.
1953 – An article by James Watson and Francis Crick describing the double helix structure of DNA is published in Nature.
1986 – A disaster occurs at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine.
1791 – Samuel Morse, inventor of the telegraph and Morse code, is born.
2001 – Dennis Tito becomes the first space tourist.
1992 – Widespread riots break out in Los Angeles after the acquittal in the Rodney King case.
1789 – George Washington is inaugurated as the first President of the USA.
1931 – The Empire State Building is opened in New York City.
1519 – Leonardo da Vinci, Italian Renaissance artist and inventor, dies.
1978 – The first mass unsolicited email (spam) is sent.
1979 – Margaret Thatcher becomes the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
1961 – Alan Shepard becomes the first American in space.
1954 – Roger Bannister becomes the first person in history to run a mile in under four minutes.
1824 – Beethoven's 9th Symphony premieres in Vienna.
1886 – Pharmacist John Pemberton invents a carbonated drink that would later become known as Coca-Cola.
1960 – The sale of the first birth control pill is approved in the USA.
1869 – The first transcontinental railroad in the USA is completed in Utah.
1997 – IBM's supercomputer Deep Blue defeats Garry Kasparov in a rematch.
1820 – Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, is born.
1981 – An assassination attempt is made on Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square in the Vatican.
1948 – The independent state of Israel is declared.
1928 – Mickey Mouse appears on screen for the first time in the silent short film 'Plane Crazy'.
1929 – The first Academy Awards ceremony, known as the Oscars, is held in Hollywood.
1792 – The New York Stock Exchange is founded.
1980 – The eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington state kills 57 people.
1536 – Anne Boleyn, the second wife of Henry VIII, is executed in London.
1873 – Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis receive a patent for blue jeans with copper rivets.
1927 – Charles Lindbergh successfully completes the first solo non-stop transatlantic flight.
1980 – The arcade game Pac-Man is released in Japan.
1934 – Famous outlaws Bonnie and Clyde are shot and killed by police.
1844 – Samuel Morse sends the first telegraph message between Washington D.C. and Baltimore.
1977 – The film 'Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope' premieres in theaters.
1897 – Bram Stoker's novel 'Dracula' is published in London.
1937 – The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco is opened to the public.
1934 – The Dionne quintuplets, the first known quintuplets to survive infancy, are born in Canada.
1953 – Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay become the first people to summit Mount Everest.
1431 – Joan of Arc is burned at the stake in Rouen.
1859 – The clock tower Big Ben in London begins operation.
1980 – The news television station CNN, the first 24-hour news network, begins broadcasting.
1953 – Elizabeth II is crowned Queen of the United Kingdom.
1965 – Ed White becomes the first American to perform a spacewalk.
1989 – The Chinese army violently suppresses protests in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1968 – Senator Robert F. Kennedy is assassinated in Los Angeles.
1944 – Allied forces land in Normandy (D-Day).
1992 – The political party HZDS is formed in Slovakia, led by Vladimír Mečiar.
1949 – George Orwell's novel 'Nineteen Eighty-Four' is published.
1934 – Donald Duck appears for the first time in an animated film.
1752 – Benjamin Franklin reportedly conducts his famous kite experiment with lightning.
1963 – Buddhist monk Thích Quảng Đức self-immolates to protest the persecution of Buddhists in South Vietnam.
1939 – The National Baseball Hall of Fame is opened in Cooperstown.
1983 – The Pioneer 10 probe becomes the first man-made object to leave the solar system.
1777 – The U.S. Congress adopts the Stars and Stripes as the official flag of the country.
1215 – King John of England is forced to sign the Magna Carta.
1963 – Valentina Tereshkova becomes the first woman in space.
1885 – The Statue of Liberty, a gift from France, arrives in New York.
1815 – Napoleon Bonaparte is defeated at the Battle of Waterloo.
1865 – The abolition of slavery is announced in Texas, a day known as Juneteenth.
1975 – Steven Spielberg's film 'Jaws' premieres in theaters.
2004 – SpaceShipOne completes the first privately funded human spaceflight.
1941 – Germany invades the Soviet Union (Operation Barbarossa).
1894 – The International Olympic Committee is founded in Paris.
1497 – John Cabot lands on the coast of North America.
1950 – The Korean War breaks out.
1997 – The first Harry Potter book is published in the United Kingdom.
1978 – The first Czechoslovak cosmonaut, Vladimír Remek, travels to space.
1914 – The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo leads to the outbreak of World War I.
2007 – The first iPhone from Apple goes on sale in the USA.
1908 – The Tunguska event, a massive explosion likely caused by a meteoroid, occurs over the Siberian taiga.
1979 – Sony introduces the Walkman, the first portable cassette player.
1937 – Amelia Earhart disappears during an attempt to circumnavigate the globe.
1863 – The Battle of Gettysburg, a key battle of the American Civil War, ends.
1776 – The Declaration of Independence is adopted in the USA.
1996 – Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal, is born.
1885 – Louis Pasteur successfully tests his rabies vaccine on a human.
2005 – A series of terrorist bomb attacks occurs in London.
1889 – The first issue of The Wall Street Journal is published.
1877 – The first Wimbledon tennis tournament begins at the All England Club.
1962 – Telstar, the world's first communications satellite, is launched.
1804 – Alexander Hamilton, one of the U.S. Founding Fathers, is mortally wounded in a duel.
1962 – The Rolling Stones play their first concert at London's Marquee Club.
1985 – The Live Aid benefit concert is held simultaneously in London and Philadelphia.
1789 – The storming of the Bastille marks the beginning of the French Revolution.
2006 – The social network Twitter is launched.
1969 – The Apollo 11 mission launches from Kennedy Space Center with the goal of landing on the Moon.
1955 – The first Disneyland opens in California.
1925 – Adolf Hitler publishes his book 'Mein Kampf'.
1848 – The first women's rights convention is held in Seneca Falls, USA.
1969 – Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin become the first humans to land on the Moon.
1983 – The lowest temperature on Earth, -89.2 °C, is recorded in Antarctica.
1933 – Wiley Post becomes the first person to fly solo around the world.
1903 – The Ford Motor Company sells its first car, the Model A.
1911 – Hiram Bingham III discovers the lost Inca city of Machu Picchu in Peru.
1978 – The first test-tube baby, Louise Brown, is born.
1953 – Fidel Castro leads an unsuccessful attack on the Moncada Barracks, marking the start of the Cuban Revolution.
1940 – Bugs Bunny appears on screen for the first time.
1914 – Austria-Hungary declares war on Serbia, beginning World War I.
1981 – The wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer takes place in London.
1956 – The phrase 'In God We Trust' becomes the official motto of the USA.
1971 – The Apollo 15 astronauts use the lunar rover on the Moon for the first time.
1981 – The music television station MTV begins broadcasting.
1939 – Albert Einstein writes a letter to President Roosevelt, warning him of the possibility of Germany developing an atomic bomb.
1492 – Christopher Columbus sets sail from Palos de la Frontera on his first voyage to the Americas.
1944 – Anne Frank and her family are arrested by German police in Amsterdam.
1962 – American actress Marilyn Monroe is found dead.
1945 – The USA drops an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima.
1974 – Philippe Petit walks on a high wire between the towers of the World Trade Center in New York.
1974 – Richard Nixon announces his resignation as U.S. President due to the Watergate scandal.
1945 – The USA drops an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Nagasaki.
1793 – The Louvre Palace in Paris is opened as a public museum.
1934 – The federal prison on Alcatraz Island is opened.
1981 – IBM introduces its first personal computer (the IBM PC).
1961 – Construction of the Berlin Wall begins in Berlin.
1945 – Japan accepts the terms of unconditional surrender, effectively ending World War II.
1969 – The legendary Woodstock music festival begins.
1977 – American singer and actor Elvis Presley dies.
1978 – The first transatlantic balloon flight is completed by the Double Eagle II.
1920 – The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, granting women the right to vote, is ratified.
1839 – The French government presents the invention of photography (the daguerreotype) to the world and makes it freely available.
1968 – Warsaw Pact troops invade Czechoslovakia to suppress the Prague Spring.
1911 – The Mona Lisa is stolen from the Louvre in Paris.
1864 – The first Geneva Convention, concerning the treatment of wounded soldiers, is signed.
1305 – Scottish national hero William Wallace is executed in London.
79 AD – The eruption of Mount Vesuvius destroys the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum.
1609 – Galileo Galilei demonstrates his first telescope in Venice.
1978 – Albino Luciani is elected Pope and takes the name John Paul I.
1883 – The eruption of the Krakatoa volcano causes one of the loudest sounds in recorded history.
1963 – Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his famous 'I Have a Dream' speech during the March on Washington.
1885 – Gottlieb Daimler patents the first motorcycle.
1967 – Thurgood Marshall is confirmed as the first African American Supreme Court Justice.
1997 – Princess Diana dies in a car crash in Paris.
1939 – Germany invades Poland, beginning World War II.
1945 – World War II officially ends with the signing of Japan's surrender aboard the USS Missouri.
1783 – The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the American Revolutionary War.
1998 – Larry Page and Sergey Brin found Google.
1972 – A terrorist attack on Israeli athletes occurs during the Munich Olympics.
1522 – The ship Victoria returns to Spain, completing the first circumnavigation of the world.
1822 – Brazil declares independence from Portugal.
1504 – Michelangelo's statue of David is unveiled in Florence.
1976 – Mao Zedong, leader of the Chinese Communist Party, dies.
2008 – The Large Hadron Collider at CERN is turned on.
2001 – Terrorists attack the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon in Washington D.C.
1959 – The Soviet probe Luna 2 becomes the first man-made object to land on the Moon's surface.
1993 – The Oslo Accords between Israel and Palestine are signed in Washington.
1752 – The British Empire adopts the Gregorian calendar, skipping 11 days.
1935 – The Nuremberg race laws are enacted in Nazi Germany.
1620 – The Mayflower sets sail from Plymouth, England, towards America.
1787 – The United States Constitution is signed in Philadelphia.
1851 – The first issue of The New York Times is published.
1893 – New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant women the right to vote.
1519 – Ferdinand Magellan sets sail on a voyage around the world.
1937 – J. R. R. Tolkien publishes the novel 'The Hobbit'.
1862 – Abraham Lincoln issues the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, freeing slaves.
1846 – German astronomer Johann Galle discovers the planet Neptune.
1948 – The Honda Motor Company is founded.
1690 – The first newspaper in America is published in Boston.
1960 – The first televised U.S. presidential debate (Nixon vs. Kennedy) takes place.
1905 – Albert Einstein publishes the article presenting the famous equation E=mc².
551 BC – According to tradition, Chinese philosopher Confucius is born.
1954 – The European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) is founded in Geneva.
1955 – American actor James Dean dies in a car accident.
1908 – Ford introduces the Model T, the first mass-produced automobile.
1869 – Mahatma Gandhi, leader of the Indian independence movement, is born.
1990 – Germany is reunified.
1957 – The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite.
1962 – The Beatles release their first single, 'Love Me Do'.
1927 – The premiere of the film 'The Jazz Singer' marks the end of the silent film era.
1959 – The Luna 3 probe photographs the far side of the Moon for the first time.
1871 – The Great Chicago Fire breaks out, destroying a large part of the city.
1989 – A mass demonstration in Leipzig signals the impending fall of the Berlin Wall.
1970 – Fiji gains independence from the United Kingdom.
1984 – Kathryn Sullivan becomes the first American woman to perform a spacewalk.
1492 – Christopher Columbus lands on an island in the Caribbean, 'discovering' America for Europeans.
1307 – On the orders of King Philip IV of France, thousands of Knights Templar are arrested and imprisoned.
1947 – Chuck Yeager becomes the first person to break the sound barrier.
1990 – Mikhail Gorbachev is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1793 – Marie Antoinette is executed during the French Revolution.
1931 – Gangster Al Capone is convicted of tax evasion.
1867 – The USA formally takes possession of Alaska from Russia.
1781 – The British army surrenders at Yorktown, effectively ending the American Revolutionary War.
1973 – The Sydney Opera House is officially opened.
1879 – Thomas Edison successfully tests his first commercially viable electric light bulb.
1962 – President Kennedy announces a naval blockade of Cuba, beginning the Cuban Missile Crisis.
2001 – Apple introduces the first iPod.
1945 – The UN Charter comes into force, officially establishing the United Nations.
1881 – Pablo Picasso, Spanish painter and sculptor, is born.
1881 – The famous gunfight at the O.K. Corral takes place in Tombstone, Arizona.
1904 – The first subway line in New York City is opened.
1886 – The Statue of Liberty is officially unveiled in New York.
1969 – The first connection is made between two computers on the ARPANET, the predecessor to the internet.
1938 – Orson Welles broadcasts his famous radio dramatization of 'The War of the Worlds', causing panic.
1517 – Martin Luther reportedly nails his Ninety-five Theses to the church door in Wittenberg, starting the Reformation.
1993 – The Maastricht Treaty comes into force, officially establishing the European Union.
1947 – Howard Hughes makes the only flight of his huge aircraft, the Spruce Goose.
1957 – The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 2 into space with the dog Laika on board.
1922 – Howard Carter discovers the entrance to Tutankhamun's tomb in the Valley of the Kings.
1605 – The Gunpowder Plot, an attempt to assassinate King James I, is discovered in England.
1860 – Abraham Lincoln is elected as the 16th President of the USA.
1917 – The October Revolution begins in Russia.
1895 – Wilhelm Röntgen discovers a new type of radiation, which he calls X-rays.
1989 – The Berlin Wall falls.
1969 – The children's educational show 'Sesame Street' premieres in the USA.
1918 – World War I ends with the signing of the armistice.
1990 – Tim Berners-Lee publishes a formal proposal for the World Wide Web.
1982 – The Vietnam Veterans Memorial is dedicated in Washington D.C.
1889 – Journalist Nellie Bly embarks on a journey to circumnavigate the globe in less than 80 days.
1971 – Intel introduces the first commercially available microprocessor, the Intel 4004.
1945 – The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is founded.
1869 – The Suez Canal is opened.
1928 – Mickey Mouse becomes famous with the premiere of the short film 'Steamboat Willie'.
1863 – Abraham Lincoln delivers his famous Gettysburg Address.
1985 – Microsoft releases the first version of its operating system, Windows 1.0.
1877 – Thomas Edison announces the invention of the phonograph, a device for recording and reproducing sound.
1963 – President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas.
1963 – The first episode of the sci-fi series 'Doctor Who' premieres in the United Kingdom.
1859 – Charles Darwin publishes his groundbreaking book 'On the Origin of Species'.
1915 – Albert Einstein presents the general theory of relativity.
1922 – Howard Carter and Lord Carnarvon become the first people in thousands of years to enter Tutankhamun's tomb.
1895 – Alfred Nobel signs his will, dedicating his fortune to establishing the Nobel Prize.
1520 – Ferdinand Magellan becomes the first European to sail from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.
1972 – Atari releases Pong, one of the first commercially successful video games.
1835 – Mark Twain, American writer, is born.
1955 – Rosa Parks is arrested in Montgomery, Alabama, leading to the bus boycott.
1804 – Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor of France in Paris.
1967 – Christiaan Barnard performs the first successful human heart transplant in Cape Town.
1998 – The first component of the International Space Station (ISS) is launched into orbit.
1791 – Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer, dies.
1877 – Thomas Edison demonstrates the first sound recording on his phonograph.
1941 – Japan attacks the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor.
1980 – John Lennon is shot and killed in New York City.
1968 – Douglas Engelbart gives 'The Mother of All Demos', publicly demonstrating the computer mouse, hypertext, and graphical user interface for the first time.
1901 – The first Nobel Prizes are awarded.
1936 – King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom abdicates to marry the divorced American Wallis Simpson.
1901 – Guglielmo Marconi receives the first transatlantic wireless signal.
1642 – Dutch navigator Abel Tasman discovers New Zealand.
1911 – Roald Amundsen and his expedition become the first people to reach the South Pole.
1791 – The Bill of Rights, the first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution, is ratified.
1773 – The Boston Tea Party, a protest against British taxes, takes place in Boston.
1903 – The Wright brothers make the first controlled, powered airplane flight at Kitty Hawk.
1892 – Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's ballet 'The Nutcracker' premieres in St. Petersburg.
1984 – The United Kingdom and China sign the agreement on the handover of Hong Kong to China in 1997.
1990 – Tim Berners-Lee launches the world's first website.
1937 – Walt Disney's first full-length animated feature film, 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs', premieres in Los Angeles.
1894 – Alfred Dreyfus is wrongly convicted of treason in Paris, beginning the Dreyfus affair.
1888 – Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh cuts off part of his ear during a mental health crisis.
1914 – An unofficial Christmas truce occurs on the Western Front during World War I.
800 – Pope Leo III crowns Charlemagne as Emperor of the Romans.
1898 – Marie and Pierre Curie announce the discovery of a new chemical element, which they name radium.
1831 – Charles Darwin embarks on his five-year voyage of discovery aboard the HMS Beagle.
1895 – The Lumière brothers hold the world's first public film screening in Paris.
1890 – The Wounded Knee Massacre occurs in South Dakota.
1922 – The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) is officially established.
1879 – Thomas Edison gives the first public demonstration of his electric light bulb.
